Title: Release of hydrocyanic acid from a chemical production plant
LessonsLearned: On April 5th, the classified installations inspectorate (DRIRE) requested that the operator submit an accident report, as well as the measures taken or to be taken and to check if this type of accident had been contemplated within the scope of the project of extension.<br><br>On April 10th, the operator presented the inspectorate with the conclusions of his post-accident analysis and the measures taken or which would be implemented in the near future in order to prevent recurrence of such an accident. It took note of these measures and no objection was made concerning putting the installations back into service.<br>The cleaning of the installations, the repair of the separator unit and the damaged piping, followed by the progressive restarting of the HCN shop, then the TGN, took place from Monday 10th through Thursday 13th April, 2000.<br><br>Corrective actions at first proposed by the operator:<br>&nbsp;* Immediate modification of the shutdown procedure,<br>&nbsp;* Immediate replacement of air by nitrogen during stripping,<br>&nbsp;* Installation of an analyser in the column's gas exhaust which is independent of the analyser used for the process, and which triggers the emergency shut-down of the stripping process if HCN concentrations &gt; 0.9% are detected,<br>&nbsp;* Installation of a flame protection system between the mist separator and the boiler, in order to avoid any flashbacks.<br><br>After several further requests, the following additional elements were adopted:<br><br>&nbsp;* The internal emergency plan is modified: The prefecture, the Regional Directorate For Industry, Research and Environment (DRIRE -- Direction REgionale de l'Industrie, de la Recherche et de l'Environnement), and the police will be informed about any gas alarm (even if triggered at very low concentrations) if it lasts longer than 30 min.;<br>&nbsp;* A flame protection system will be installed upstream of the boiler with the next major shutdown of the installations;<br>&nbsp;* The operating mode is modified for the phases following the exhaustion of the HCN reaction chain <br>&nbsp;- in order to reduce the HCN concentration below the LEL concentrations, stripping is begun with nitrogen in the liquid as well as in the gas phase<br>&nbsp;- Change over to air stripping for concentrations below 0.7%;<br>&nbsp;- Lowering of the alarm threshold and installation of a safety system acting on the backflow rate (recirculated rate of flow) of the liquid phase;<br>&nbsp;<br>&nbsp;- Stripping will be continued until a HCN concentration of 1 ppm in the liquid phase is reached.<br>&nbsp;* Moreover, the operator proposes improving the sprinkling with acidic solution inside the column in order to avoid the risk of polymerisation caused by low acidity.<br>&nbsp;* Analysis of two possible worsening scenarios for the accident of 29 March 2000:<br>&nbsp;- shut-off failure of the tank valves: the release would have continued with 1 t/h of N2 with 2,6% of HCN, i.e. with 26 kg/h of HCN and a lethal limit zone (ZOLEM zone limite effets mortels) below 50 m;<br>&nbsp;- Propagation of the explosion beyond the .droplet separation vessel up to the .absorption column head and bursting of the latter. Release from the .column head of 30 t/h of air with 5.6% HCN, at a height of 30 m, and the formation of a pool on the ground with a maximum concentration of 5.6% HCN <br>&nbsp;# First release of 0.5 kg/s HCN : a limit zone between reversible/irreversible effects of 230 m.<br>&nbsp;# Evaporation of the pool: limit zone between reversible/irreversible effects of the first scenario<br>-&nbsp; limit zone between reversible/irreversible effects of the worst case scenario considered for the modification project for the installation.<br>&nbsp;The effects of such an accident would not go beyond the boundaries of the site.<br>&nbsp;* Launching of an inspection program for procedures and instrumentation during start-up and shut-down phases: 38 situation data sheets have been prepared.<br><br>
EmergencyResponce_Descr: Since at 19:00 no consequences for the personnel or the environment had been reported, the operator decides not to activate the off-site (external) emergency plan, and the internal contingency&nbsp; plan is terminated, while the order for the employees' confinement is withdrawn.<br><br>The inspectorate for classified installations (DRIRE) and the mayors of the 3 neighbouring Municipalities were informed, but the prefecture was not&nbsp; informed by the operator.<br><br>

Site_Description: The Chalampé (68) platform comprises 4 chemical plants:<br>The plant operates various installations subject to authorisation (A) and to authorisation with public utility easement (AS). Its activities are regulated by the order of the prefect of November 23rd 1999. The establishment is also subject to the Seveso II directive.<br><br>The worst case scenario considered for the site is a leak from an ammonia tank, the release of hydrocyanic acid is also considered.<br>This scenario considers the rupture of a pipe carrying HCN to an adjoining unit:<br>- release of 15.8 kg/s of HCN during 360 seconds (6 minutes), a limit zone of irreversible effects (ZOLERI) of 1,400 m and a limit zone of deadly effects (ZOLEM) of 780 m.<br>
Installation_Description: The damaged installations, used for the synthesis of hydrocyanic acid (HCN), belong to the plant's adiponitrile production unit. <br>HCN is obtained by the chemical reaction process between ammonia and methane.<br>NH3 + CH4 = HCN + 3 H2<br>Liquid ammonia (NH3) is supplied to the unit via a pipeline from a neighbouring plant or from a storage tank.<br><br>The methane obtained from the natural gas, has to be purified before reacting with the ammonia in order to eliminate heavy hydrocarbons (ethane, propane, butane, etc.). These substances significantly limit the yield of the synthesis process, shorten the service life of the catalysts, and produce excessive amounts of higher nitriles. <br>

Causes_Description: The analysis of the accident was conducted by an interdisciplinary work group. Its potential causes were examined&nbsp; using the failure tree method. A safe-T-tree was then constructed after having eliminated the highly improbable potential causes: a flashback produced from the boiler was stopped by the separator tank (H1191).<br>According to the operator, the accident was caused by:<br>&nbsp;- the presence of polymers in the tower which slowed down the drainage of HCN,&nbsp; - at the start of the air stripping phase, an operation conducted with an HCN content higher than normal in the residual gases, the normal drainage of the trains not having been conducted,<br>&nbsp; - the presence of several inconsistencies in the implementation procedure:<br>&nbsp;- since 1989, the stripping procedure has consisted of a blocking phase based on a safety threshold level set at 5% HCN in liquid phase. This threshold is erroneous, stripping at 10°C with an HCN concentration &gt; 1.2% in the liquid leading the lower explosive limit (LEL = 6%) of the hydrocyanic acid in gas phase to be reached. At the time of the accident, the HCN concentration of the liquid at the base of tower H2242 was 1.2%, compatible with the threshold.<br>&nbsp;- the sample of liquid analysed at the base of tower H2242, containing 1.2% HCN, was not representative of the real HCN amount of the train.<br>A posteriori, the average concentration of the amount analysed was 2%.<br>&nbsp;- the gas phase HCN analyser present at the tower head was not adapted and did not allow the operators to be alerted. The device was limited to "normal" operating ranges: alarm at 0.9% and no measurement beyond 1.2%.<br>&nbsp;- the operating mode did not explicitly indicate the action to be taken for a concentration<br>greater than 0.9%.<br>By reducing the air outputs, the operators:<br>- reduced the speed of the gases in the line toward the boiler,<br>- promoted flashback,<br>- increased the HCN content in the air and the risk of exceeding the L.E.L.<br><br>

Consequence_Description: The operator evaluated the quantity of HCN released into the atmosphere at 25 kg and the property damage was limited: the line to the boiler was expanded over 1m in length and a the collar of the separator tank was ripped over 400 cm².<br><br>No consequences were observed on the personnel and the plant's environment.<b><br><br></b>
